div.head: EASTERNS AND EUROPEANS
div.p: The Geographical Society is to be congratulated upon the success of its opening meeting. It would have been difficult to find a topic of greater promise, or a lecturer whose name could prove more attractive, than those provided. In saying this we do not, of course, in any way depreciate either Sir William Willcocks or the subject on which he was to have spoken had it been possible to carry out the programme for the session as it was originally drawn up. Sir William' is one of our old, tried, and esteemed friends, and his subject one of perennial interest and one which he has unrivalled ability in discussing, but Mr. Benito Sylvain is as yet a new found lion and has the charm of the novelty we all so much prize in Egypt. Although he did not introduce us to a field of thought altogether unfamiliar, he gave us the opportunity of seeing it from an entirely new point of view. It is quite needless for us to say, that in the object to which he appears to have devoted himself,-that of promoting, good-will between the European colonists of the East and the Eastern peoples with whom they are in contact,-Mr. Sylvain has our most cordial sympathy. To promote that object has long been, as our readers are aware," one of the first of the principles upon which the Gazette is conducted, and it is therefore from no hostility to the speaker, or to his aims, that we feel compelled to criticise his lecture. Notwithstanding the great ability Mr. Sylvain undoubtedly possesses, and the striking proof his lecture offers of the high intellectual development his race is capable of, we cannot but think that his lecture as a whole w rather a confutation then a confinuation of his view. It is so because the whole argument upon which it was founded is in itself evidence of that inability to see and comprehend the force of facts, or to draw logical conclusions from them, that is one of the chief justifica tions of the European's criticism of the Eastern peoples. The adage that "It is the excepti that proves the rule," though time honoured is somewhat of a dangerous guide to accept, and may easily be misapplied. To cite, as Mr. Sylvain did,a number of admittedly exceptional cases, instances of Negroes and other Easterns who can claim to have shown mental or other capacity, entitling them to high positions among their European confrères, is absolutely no answer whatever to the assumption, of which Mr. Sylvain complains, that the Eastern is normally inferior to the European in intellectual power. We shall not stop here to show that the instances to which Mr. Sylvain referred are, apart from other considerations, insufficient to prove his case, inasmuch as scarcely any of the names he cited are those of pure-blooded Easterns, for in this respect it seems to us that he might have done much better. Had he, for example, looked to India for evidence of this kind be might there have found a long list of the names of men of the purest Asiatic descent who have held their own with Europeans in almost every branch of intellectual labour.

The fact is, that the argument drawn from such cases only begs the question, for the question, really at issue is not that of the capacity of individuals but that of the capacity of the races. Hence the tu quoque argument that Mr. Sylvain adopted, his attempt to show that some of the lower classes of Europeans are mentally but little, if at all, above the level of the Asiatic and African peoples, was not only wide of the mark but wholly inapplicable. Anglo-Indians readily admit that in "finesse" and some other points the average educated Indian is beyond them, but the admission, so far from justifying the claim of intellectual equality so often founded upon it, in very truth disproves it, for the superiority, such as it is, is barren and unprolific. In India, indeed, it is one of the happiest signs of the times that this latter reproach, which is the one that the European regards as constituting the essential difference between himself and the Eastern, would appear to be on the eve of disappearing, for Indians have of late shown a growing capacity for initiative work in several directions that promises to be most fruitful in the not far-off fature. But the Indian has never been so distant intellectually from the European as the Negro is from the Indian; and though it would therefore be a fundamental fallacy to argue from the one to the other in support of Mr. Sylvain's views, it is obvious that if the Indian has not yet bridged the gulf between himself and the European, very slight indeed must be the probability of the Negro doing so within any near time. It is to be noted, too, that Mr. Sylvain has ignored the really essential points, the lack of healthy ambition and of constructive initiative that distinguishes the faces he so ably defends. But in the end the mere fact that it is necessary to plead for these races is very largely an admission of the justice of the case against them. If any one of the races that are now beld to be "inferior" desires to see itself acknowledged as an equal of those held in higher esteem, the one and only course by which it can attain to realise its wish is by following the example of the Japanese and showing the world, the powers it possesses. It is an utterly false argument to say that the races have not the opportunities or facilities for self-improvement. The exact contrary is the real truth. There is scarcely any important" Oriental people of to-day that has not infinitely greater advantages and facilities for self advancement than had the English people before the passing of the Reform Bill, the French before the Revolution, or the Germans or Italians before the dawn of liberty in their countries. The individual Egyptian, Indian, African, or Asiatic in any of the European co lonies of the East hasa hundred and a thousand fold the opportunity of lifting himself in the social and intellectual scale that any European ever had prior to the middle of the last century, and while this is so, it is useless for Mr. Sylvain to argue, even indirectly, that the condition of the races for whom he pleads is in any way to be attributed to the failure of Europeans to assist them. That we should do so is not only right but in a large sense our duty and interek yet between this and the view that Mr. Sylvain seems to represent there is a great difference. None the less we willingly close this article with sincere and earnest wishes that Mr. Sylvain may ever meet with the utmost access in the prosecution of the object-a noble one-to which he has devoted himself

div.head:
A RUSSIAN SORTIE.
DESTROYER AT CHI-FU.
BRINGS DESPATCHES FROM STOESSEL
POSITION OF PORT ARTHUR.
SHIP BLOWN UP.

div.p: The Russian torpedo-bost destroyer Ras- torpay has brought despatches from General Stoessel. The Russians afterwards blew up the destroyer.

The Russian destroyer Raztorpay arrived here yesterday evening in a heavy snowstorm, and anchored alongside the Reckitelei. She notified Prince Ching that she would disarm. She brought important despatches for St. Petersburg, and also a copy of the Nory Krai, in which it was stated that a Japanese destroyer, whilst laying mines on the 11th inst, was surprised by the Russian battleship Retrisan, and sunk.

The Russian destroyer Rastorpay left Port Arthur at midnight amidst a blinding mow storm. She was chased by the Japanese de stroyers but outdistanced them. The sailors are healthy, free from care, and do not appear to have suffered from privations. The officers declare that the position is as good as it was two months ago, the main forts not being captured. They admit that the shells have damaged the Bayas's engines, which are being repaired. Their optimism was obviously over drawn, even to the extent of ostentatiously displaying joints of beef when the corres pondents boarded the Rastorpsy. (Reuter)
The Russians have blown up the Rastorpay.

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR.
GEN. STOESSEL WOUNDED, WILL NOT GIVE UP COMMAND
SPIRITS OF THE TROOPS.
div.p: Beater's correspondent before Port Arthur cabled on the 11th inst. that General Stoessel was wounded and obliged to go into hospital. He, however, refused to relinquish his command, and has ordered the garrison to die at their posts rather than surrender. The spirits of the troops are damped by the continuous work, the lack of supplies, and the hopelessness of the defence. (Router)

div.head:
NILE NAVIGATION.
NO CAUSE FOR ALARM.
TOURIST TRAFFIC WILL BE UNIMPEDED.
div.p: The great tourist agencies of Egypt, Messrs. To Cook & Son (Egypt), Limited, and the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Com pany, do not view with any alarm the prospects of the low Nile interfering with their river traffic. Everything points to an unprecedented Nile tourist season, and the announcement that Nile navigation by steamers of deep drught will be impracticable from the begin ning of February next, owing to the low flood, will have no effect on the tourist steamers, which are specially built with a light draught.

No definite official statement can be given by the Public Works Ministry in regard to the probable state of the river before Christmas Messrs. Cook do not, however, anticipate any difficulty in carrying out their season's pro gramme of Nile trips.

Of course, the river will be low, but there is a great difference between a shallow Nile and the absolute stoppage of navigation. For example, the steamers of the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company can steam in three feet of water. As a specimen of how wonderfully the Nile steamers are constructed in order to cope with the shallowness of the river at times, we may cite the cases of Messrs. Cook's Serapis and Oomar, which are, respect ively, 125 and 110 feet in length and only have a draught of 2 feet 6 inches. The bookings for the river trips are in advance of those at the same period last year, and there are good grounds for believing that last year's record season will be surpassed this year and that the 1904-5 river season will be most successful.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive is expected to return to Koub beh Palace to day from his estates at Mous touroud.
Tomorrow his Highness will attend the com memoration service at the Citadel Mosque in honour of Mohamed Aly.
In the evening his Highness will give "Iftar" at Abdeen Palace to native notables.

div.head: cbUNCIL OF MINISTERS
div.p: At the Council of Ministers held yesterday the Cali of Egypt, who was present, protested against the appointment of Sheikh Abdel- Rahman Pods as Cadi of the Mehkemeh Sharieh, on the ground that the appointment had been made without consulting the ulema A lengthy discussion followed.

div.head: POST OFFICE FRAUDS
div.p: We are authorised officially to contradict the statement made by a Cairo contemporary to the effect that in consequence of the recent frauds, committed by some employés of the Postal Administration, the Finance Ministry had decided on naming inspectors for the purpose of making regular periodical inspee tions of the different offices and books. M. Pet ogvitch was, at the request of the Postmaster General, specially deputed last week to in vestigate the irregularities that occurred at Alexandria a few days back. Possibly this fact gave occasion for these erroneous statements

On Monday, we had Le Gendre de M. Poirier, good but in our opinion not equal to some preceding performances Coquelin was, of course, admirable, but he was not well seconded by all the company. After the play H.H. the Khedive received M. Coquelin for a few minutes, during which his Highness expressed his regret that the calls of public and private business had prevented him from paying a previous visit to the Opers. His Highness was graciously pleased to promise a donation to the association in aid of distressed and retired actors, of which M. Coquelin is the president. After the first act, M. Rosenberg, in a neat little speech, appealed to the generosity of the Cairene public, and over 1,500 francs were collected by Mmes. 8. Devoyod, Lerand, and Bonchatel. Tuesday's performance reached a much higher level. The actors were all loudly ap planded and Coquelin was greeted with especial warmth by the public, who had doubtless heard of his promise to return to us soon. May nothing hinder the fulfilment of the vow!

M. Silvain, the eminent societaire of the Co- médie Française, will give a lecture at the New Khedivial Hotel on Saturday next, at 5 p.m., on "T'Art de dire" (The Art of Speaking), for the benefit of the Free Popular University. The lecture will be illustrated by examples, drawn from the great French poets. Mue. Louise Silvain will also take part in the proceedings.
Tickets may be had at the University, or at Schuler's and Nacamuli's Bookstalls, price P.T. 10.

div.head: EGYPT AND THE AGREEMENT.
div.p: During the course of the debate in the French Chamber this day week on the Anglo- Prench Agreement, M. de Pressensé said that, as for Egypt, French diplomacy had been well inspired in accepting what it could not undo, and in connecting this question with that of Morocco, the arrangement concerning which only aimed at the development of civilisation by pacific methods. He concluded, amid loud applause, by predicting that the day might come when union between England and France would be the powerful instrument of peace in Europe and in the world at large.
M. Denys Cochin, a Conservative, had some criticisms for the agreement, particularly with respect to Egypt; but he wound up by saying that he would vote for it.

As to Egypt, M. Delcassé said that he would be wanting in respect to the Chamber if by any artifice of language he should seek to diminish the value of the concession made to England in giving that nation complete liberty there. It was an easy argument that we could continue to be reserved about the future. That would mean embittering relations, so, in the interest of his country, he signed with England the agreement relative to Egypt. M. Delcassé further said that the fund of the Egyptian Debt was created in 1876, to safeguard European interests when the Government of the Khedive suspended payment. Ten years later the interest was reduced, and the debt unified. Could France at that time refuse assent to the reimbursement of the debt! He did not think so, but he resolved to have some profit out of the assent. Thus the product of the land-tax would be applied to the payment of that debt. The arrangement so made was favourable to Egypt and to holders of securities. France had also the right to look after the antiquities of Egypt, and their schools would continue to work as usual.

The ball given on Tuesday night at the Hellenic Club, Cairo, was a very brilliant spectacle, the decorations, palms, flowers, and the national colours being very striking. On their arrival the guests were received by M.M. Gianaelis, Rostowitz Bey, and other leading members of the club, and at 10 p.m. the com ing of Commodore Coundouriotis and the Greek Diplomatic Agent was greeted by the Greek National Hymn. Rostowite Bey then expressed his pleasure at welcoming the offi oers, and at 10 p.m. the ball opened with the Greek national dance, in which M. and Mile Gennadis, Rostowitz Bey, and M. Meims rachi, among others, took part. The usual nineteenth-century dances followed, and were prolonged to so late an hour that the punctual appearance of the gallant officers at 9am. yesterday on board the Tramway Company's steamer was almost a surprise. A visit was paid to the Cairo Barrage and M. Salvago's factory, and it was not till 3 pm. that the party returned to leave the Cairo station at 4 pm. amid the farewells and cheers of a great number of spectators who had come to see

We understand that Commodore Coun douriotis expressed himself delighted with the reception accorded to himself and his officers in Cairo and warmly thanked the Greek com- munity for their generous hospitality and active patrioti

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: The London Stock Exchance has received an application to allow the following security to be quoted in the Official List: Agricultural Bank of Egypt, £1,250,000 34 per Cent. Bonds, redeemable 1924-49, in lieu of the scrip now quoted

The Times of yesterday week publishes the following announcement as to Lord Cromer's movements on the previous day: "The Earl of Cromer crossed from Dover to Calais yes terday." The Globe of Wednesday evening goes one further and mentions the peer with whom Lord Cromer made the passage across the Channel, for our London evening contemporary declares that "the Earl of Cromer and Lord Redesdale crossed from Dover to Calais yea

terday." On the day after Lord Cromer was seen crossing the Channel, he was present at the King's Birthday Review in Abdeen square. Either the Times is grossly inaccurate or Lord Cromer has a double, which deceives even the experienced reporters of our great London contemporary and led them to fall into an error which is otherwise absolutely inexcusable.

PRACAS IN A CAFE-A serious dispute arose between three Greeks and a dumb com patriot in a coffee shop in Attarin street, Alexandria, yesterday, in the course of which the mute received several wounds at the hands of the three men, who amailed him with empty bottles, glasses, and chairs. The man, becom ing infuriated, rushed into the kitchen of the café and, shatching up a knife, stabbed one of his assailants in the abdomen, but not fatally. The owner of the coffee shop fired three abots in the air, which brought a policeman, who, with the amistance of the passers-by and ghafir, arrested the four disputante,

div.head: WAR AT OUR DOORS.
div.p: RUSSIANS PEAR ATTACK IN EGYPTIAN WATERS.

The Hus, of St. Petersburg, states that the possibility of a Japanese attack on the Baltic Pleet in Egyptian waters is proved by reports which have been received from Admiral Rodjestvensky throughout the route.

We do not quite share the fear expressed by our Russian contemporary, but we understand, nevertheless, that great vigilance is being exercised along the Suez Canal by the authori ties, Coast Guards being actively patrolling
M. Maximo, Russian Consal-General, left Cairo yesterday evening for Port Said. It is stated he will accompany the vessels of the Baltic Fleet during their passage through the

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: London, November 11. Before this reaches you great events will probably have taken place, making for peace in the Far East. Our last foretold that we should have important news to send you in our next. We are now at liberty to say that during the past few days the Powers have-to use a hackneyed phrase-"been using their best endeavour to put an end to the awful, sacrifice of life and property now taking place in Manchuria. We understand all are agreed as to this, even the belligerents them selves. The great and almost insuperable difficulty is, how is it to be brought about! It needs no explanation from us to shew that diplomacy has a hard task to perform. Europe realises that there is a limit to the "knocking out" process of Russia. France, the holder of many millions of Russian bonds, is beginning to realise that the process of nursing the "baby" is not only a costly one, but, should Rassis be further damaged (her internal troubles also are not to be ignored in this respect), the weight of this "baby" may prove altogether too beavy a burden, the financial consequences of which would be too disastrous to contemplate.

Japan, also, reasonable state of mind at the present moment, and prepared to accept terms, on the advice of her friends, which at the beginning of the war were out of the question. We shall have more to say as to this next week.

The Government has been meeting con stantly, and the Representatives of the Foreign Powers are in daily communication with Lord Lansdowne. The agreement between this country and America is a significant fact. The Hull outrage is no longer, and has not for days past been, the cause of further anxiety; in diplomatic circles the affair is looked upon as closed.

The consequence of the above is that a general improvement i tone has taken place in our stock markets, and a distinct increase in activity in business in all departments. The firmness of Egyptian Stocks is still quite a feature, and almost all prices mark a further advance since last week. Salt and Soda shares have again been in strong demand. This buying comes almost entirely from Egyptian sources, and the shares are being shipped out to your side, with the natural result that the London Market is being rapidly cleared out, and all buying orders here have a proportionately strong effect on the price, which has risen to 33/- buyers. It is reported that these purchases, are due to a desire on the part of the buyers to dequire complete control of the company thereby. There is also a short supply of Land shares in this market; Delta Lands being strong at 2-3/16 National Banks bold their price wonderfully at 23, whilst Agriculturals for the moment are easier at 10-15/16. There has also been some support for Egyptian Markets at 25

There are signs of a genuine revival in South Africans. Both the labour returns and the output shew good figures, consequently there has been more active business during the last few days than for a long time past American stocks are still buoyant, and keep well up to the top prices; in fact, the general outlook is more encouraging than it has been for many months past.

A supplement to the London Gazette an nounces that the King has been pleased to promote Major-General Ronald Bertram lane, CVO, C.B, to the rank of Knight Commander of the Royal Victorian Order. Major-General Lane served in the Zulu war in 1879, in the Boer war in 1881, and in the Egyptian war in 1882. He commanded the garrison at Alex andria from 1898, when he was getted Major-General, to 1901, and a brigade at Malta from 1901 to 1908. He was Military Secretary at the War Office from 1903

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: La Cour vient de rendre son jugement dans cette affaire. Elle condamne M. Léo Cassir à payer le droit de 5 ajo sur Is valeur réelle des terres qu'il a achetées à Kale Dawar. Cette valeur ayant été estimée par l'expert à 250 pisstres le fed- dan, e'est done sur 4,625 L.E. que M Cassir devra payer le droit et non sur L.E. 205 comme le porte le prix d'achat de ses 2,050 feddans
un aperçu des motifs invoquée par

Toate Is question roale sur l'application de l'article 54 du tarif des frais de justice. Or le dit article doabe au goffer le droi de recourir à une expertise si la valeur déclarée dans les actes soumis à la taxe proportionnelle lui pralt intérieure d'an dixième à la valeur réelle.

Les premiers juges avaient établi Is distinction suivante: l'expertise était admissible partout où la loi mentionnait la valeur somme devant servir de base so caleal des droits, par exemple, dans le antes de denation, de vente d'arafruit on d'ange, d'échange; elle était loadmissible lorsque le mot pris était employé. L Cour rejette cette distfaction comm abtils et contraire à l'esprit de la loi. Les termes de priz es de valeur s'expl quent par le fait que les ventes comportent us prix déterminé, tandis qu'il n'en est pas de méme pour la donation, l'échan

La distinction est de plus contraire à l'esprit de la loi, car il est bien évi dent que le législateur a voulu fournir au fise un moyen sir de déjouer les fraudes; et l'on ne comprendrait pas dans ce cas comment les ventes, qui sont les transsne tions de beaucoup les plus fréquentes et Is plas productives, saraient été privénde fat contrôle. Il ne s'ensuit pas, comme

en l'objecte, que le gr-r sarait toujours le drois d'intenter un procès et le moyer de prouver que l'achetear a fraudé le de Rien n'est plus difficile, en efft, que d prouver la simula lon du prix. Cett preuve étant la plupart du temps im possib'e à établir, le go fler perdrait pres que toujours son prorès

Si d'ailleurs on s'en rapporte à la loi française da 22 frimaire Fan VIII qui a servi de base à la législation mist on voit qu'aux termes de cette loi il n'y pas de doute que les ventes ne puissen étre contrôlées par expertise. Le principe du droit d'expertise une fois établi, on en dédait que le droit proportionnel doit être perça sur la valeur réelle. Le caractère aléstoire de l'achst ne peut entrer en lign de compte suprès du fe. L'art. 69 da tarif en est une preuve, puisque, sax termes de cet article, quelle que soit la esuse pour laquelle les actes restent sans effet, le droit perça ne sers pas restitas. En résumé Is Cour prononce que les droits de vente doivent être payés sur la valeur réelle des terrains et non sar lear priz déclaré de vente. L earacère alés toire de la chose veadae ne change rien à ce prinsipe.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: Les raisons pour lesquelles nous avons trouvé M. Bilvain mieux doué que M. Novell pour jouer Le Père Lebonnard mettent l'artiste français dans un état évident d'infériorité vis à vis de son rival dans le rôle de Louis XI, le roi méfiant, eruel et Canteleux qui tremble devant François de Psale ou son médecin et ne eraint pas de faire disparaitre tous ceux qui le gênent, son père même, par l'assist on le poison. Ce rôle tout d'asture était bien mieux adapté à Novelli, et c'est un vrai tour de force pour Bilvain d'avoir réad à l'inter prêter comme il l'a fait, au point de mé riter les éloges des admirateurs de N velli

Le public a été cependant moins enthou- siant que dans Le Fère Lebonnard, mais eela tient, eroyons-nous, d'une part à l pièce elle-même et, d'autre part, à l'exée- tion plus ou moins défectueuse de certains roles secondaires. M. Jean Renaud que nous avons admiré dans les pièses précé dentes n'a pas été-asi heureux dans le rôle du das de Nemours. Il y manqusit un peu de vivacité. Les ro'es de Commine et de François de Paule ont été z bien nns, le premier par M. F. erat et le second par M. Bené Llos'ère. Quelques katres ont été rendas d'une façon plus ou moins isfaisante. Da elé des dames l'inter prétation a été meilleure Mme Silvaina été bien dans le rôle si difficile da dauphin et alles Bival et Barat dans ceux de Marie et de Maribe.

Ce soir on dinae Grieflidis, mystère en 3 actes et en vers de MM. Armond Sil- vestre et Rag. Morand. Il y aura un inter mà le par M Hilvain et la représentation so terminers par Le Passant, pière en 1 pete de Frangole Ooppée.

div.head: GUNNY BAG MARKET.
div.p: SCHRAGER BROR CALCUTTA MARK! REPORT FOR WEEK ENDING 3rd NOVEMBER, 1904.
Trade in general has not been particularly brisk, the high level of prices undoubtedly checking business, as there has been a fair amount of enquiry during the week with but little result.

Standard descriptions of goods for deliveries up to the close of the year can for the most part only be obtained for secondhand hold ers, while for special weight and sized fabrics mills have to be dealt with, and they can only work for more distant deliveries.

Heavy C bags, both 40 hd, and 42 unbd, are offered at a concession in price by specu lators to clear their October holdings, while for such of their goods as can be prepared with a stripe, an advance is paid on last week's prices, against orders from the Far East.

E bags are in strong request and have ad- vanced in price for all deliveries up to June next year, while a lb. 6 porter B twills are apparently not wanted at prosent, and although there is no actual giving way in price, local rosales by public auction on account of default- ers has somewhat weakened the position, 8 porter twills, on the other hand, are hardening in valon, brought on by enquiries from the Australian Colonies for this month's require ments of cornacks.
There is a good deal of enquiry for forward deliveries, but the high prices asked, because of the uncertain position of loose jute, checks business, mills in most instances quoting pro hibitive rates

HESSIANS have attracted a good deal of attention, and the large business put through in both nine and eleven porter cloth, as also Wheat Pockets, has been almost exclusively of a speculative nature, and were it not for the scarcity that must prevail later for the finer qualities of Jute, prices paid would appear to be much inflated. Outside markets are doing nothing, if we exclude the small orders that come up from the Plate, and although there must undoubtedly be a good deal of buying to be done for America, the production would be quite equal to the demand, provided mills ex perience no trouble with their labour, and Jute be more plentiful than is now generally expect ed. At the close the tendency is for present rates keeping firm, quotations being
40 104 Por Nov, Dee. both sine and eleven porter cloth are scarce and there are buyers at Rs.7-14-0 and Rs.10-2, which are the last prices

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.

p.hi: Egyptian Cotton has been in fair demand. Fally Good Fair Brown is very scarce, and quotations are quite nominal. Good and Fine are raised ad. per lb. and Upper Egyptians d 4. per ib.

div.p: For Fatures there has been a fairly active market. The following are the closing quotations

p.hi: American Patures. The market this week has again displayed a fair amount of activity, and there have been several fluctuations of a few points up and down. To-day's closing values, however, shew very little change from those of last Thursday.

div.p: There is no new feature in the situation. Crop movements continue on a free scale, there is very little outside speculation, and the general estimate of the crop remains round about 11 millions. We are unable to form any decided opinion, with continued large receipts, etc., we should expect to see prices somewhat lower, but unless the crop is going to largely exceed prosent expectations, we do not anticipate any very material decline The latest quotations are, delivery- Nov. 5.31 Jan./Feb. 5.31 Apl/May 5.36 Nov./Dec. 5.29 Feb/Mar. 5.33 May/June 5.37 Dec/Jan. 5.29 Mar./Apl. 5.34 June/July 5.37 July/Aug. 4.31

div.head: EGYPTIAN GOLD MINING.
div.p: It must be nearly five years ago since Mr. C. J. Alford was sent to Egypt by the Victoria lu vestment Corporation upon what he, so doubt, considered was a wild goose chase. The present writer happened to be in Cairo when that some what serious pessimist returned from a six months' trip in the desert. The two clubs were fall of gossip. The Turf, noted for its young Moods, led by the excitable and versatile John son Pasha, was quite inclined to believe any thing. But the Khedivial Club, at which the Leed dined, and gave a tone to the whole official set of Pashas, Armenians and Princes, assumed a most superior air. The Geological Department had but recently reported to the Lord that no gold mines existed in Egypt. This was official. The Lord was benevolently inclined. "If gold mines exist, by all means fad them; but don't forget the opinion of the Geological Survey." Sir Elwin Palmer asked Rogers Pasha what he thought, and Rogers Pasha simply scoffed:-"I will eat all the gold they ever find here." So Palmer sent more piastres out to his oil wells on the Red Sea and decided that Rogers, the cock- sure, was again right. Moxley, the bank man, being Irish, had imagination. I think he believed. I fancy Mitchell Innes also believed.. No one else did. Some were too polite to say that the whole thing was a ramp. Others were not. The serious-minded Mr. Alford told his story. He had found gold mines; whether rich or poor, he knew not; but that they were gold mines admitted of no doubt. Gorst unofficially thought that the whole duty of man consisted in finding winners; but, as Financial Secretary, signed a concession, and sighed at the ridiculous waste of good money. So ended the first act of the Egyptian gold mines drama. Then those long-headed Chamberlains took the matter up, and a company was formed and work begun; and, as Gorst was quite willing to sign as many concessions as enterprising speculators chose to apply for, by the end of a year all Egypt and most of the Sudan had been cut up. There is no doubt that these specula tors went blind. The whole country was an unexplored desert-waterless wastes of mountain-treeless and barren. The climate was superb, and camel riding is healthy exercise when you get over the first bump; so pros pectors wandered about, backed by high sound- ing syndicates, most of which had no money, and very few even the vaguest idea of where their concessions were. But none drew blanks -all came back with reports, more or less accurate, of large groups of ancient gold mines. The syndicates promptly turned them- selves into companies, and in the City, at any rate, Egypt was a goldfield second only to the Rand. In the meantime the Egyptian Mines Exploration Company had been steadily working upon one of their most likely centres-Um Kas-and their results attracted the attention of John Taylor and Sons, who had, at the instigation of Sir James Carmichael, taken charge of a piece of un- attractive desert. They went into Egypt seriously, and when the solemn Robert Taylor told one of his shareholders' meetings that the great Queen street firm believed in the future of Egypt, a mild flutter went through mining circles South Africa was in the throes of war. Western Australia was suffering from the machinations of dishonest directorates. Here was a new gamble. The gamble came and went. Whether the great British public ever took a hand is uncertain. Possibly not. But that the City was keenly interested in quite sure. The City man saw a chance of getting in low down, and took it. Money went out to Egypt for development work. How far has that money gone! Has it produced any tangible results Let us take Um Rus. The main shaft is down 500 ft.; a 10-head battery with rock drills and winding plant is on the spot, and will be at work at the end of the year. The reef is 2 ft. wide, and averages over a long shoot an ounce. Allowance mast be made for loss, but the net gain may be 15 dwts. This at Um Ros, with cheap labour and transport, will pay a dividend upon the £150,000 capital. Then, we have the Nile Valley, about which so much has been said, and in which there has been a good deal of share gambling. This mine was only down 157 ft. when the water came in and pumpe had to be sent out. These are at work, and the mine is how unwatered. A 10-head battery is being put tp and should be crushing carly in the new year. In the meantime, a good deal of rich specimen rock has been treated, and this year over 700 os won. They have a good reef at Nile Valley, and though delayed by water and various other causes, there is no reason to think the mine will not turn out well. Adjoin ing it is the North Nile Valley, where again rich specimens have been found and £2,750 worth won. Mr. Sleeman, the manager, reports that he has 240 tons at grass which should go 3 os North Nile Valley may be described as a rich prospect. Another equally rich prospect is Atallah, which is being worked by the Central Egypt Exploration Company. Here the main shaft is down about 200ft, and they got a ref which averages 7 os. Naturally if there is any amount of this Atallah will be heard of again. All these three mines-Nile Valley, North Nile Valley and Atallah-are distinctly hopeful, but none of them have enough development work done to justify their being called more than extremely promising espects. This cannot be said of the Taylor mine in the Sudan, called Om Nabardi. Here Taylors think so well of the property that they are building a railway 30 miles in length to connect with the Government line, and thongh not down to any great depth, a good deal of work has been done, 1,500ft of drives being reported from January to September this year. The values vary from 5 oes to 10 dwts, but as the pay shoot is rich the lower values are not important. As far as one can see, Om Nabardi is to-day (for whatever that may be worth) the best mine in Egypt. The Egyp tian Mines Exploration Company are work ing upon a good reef at Eridia, which goes well over an ounce, and is 2 ft. wide, but enough wk has not been done to completely prove the property. The same company is also working at Patira, where an inclined shaft is down 420 ft on the vein-the second deepest shaft in Egypt. The values at Fatirs are jumpy-pos sibly the expenditure of ten or twenty thousand pounds would open up a big mine bere-but with values ad erratic it is evident that a pay shoot has not been obtained yet. Nubia De velopment is prospecting its large area with eight shafts, none of which are at any depth, and lignite having been found near, they are drilling for coal. P. O. Wilson, the engineer in charge, is a very capable man, and as he thinks well of his property, it must be reckoned with. The Sudan Exploration Company is working upon a concession near Suakin, and numberless rich reefs have been found, but not enough work has been done to form any definite opinion. To sum up. Four years work has been done. Two mines have been opened up to a considerable extent-Um Ras and Um Nabardi Three very rich prospects have been found- Nile Valley, North Nile Valley, and Atallah- the former may turn into a rich mine in a week. One prospect not rich, but with possibilities, exists in Eridia; another more speculative in Fatirs. The best prospecting areas in which no real mining work has been done are Nubias, the Gold and Gem (Streeter's), and the Gabait, where rich assays have been taken. But, on the whole, Egyptian mining is distinctly honest. Taylors, Alford, Lake and Carrie, Wilson, Western, Llewellyn Williams and Thomas are reliable, and not one would put his name to a report which was not absolutely correct. The development is bound to be slow, but the future seems more or less assured. The field as a whole compares more or less with the Mysore. Labour is cheap and good, and water, though scarce at first, is now too plentiful, and trans port is moderate.

div.head: ENGLAND THE ENEMY.
div.p: Herr August Niemann, author of the book entitled "Der Weltkring," which caused a good deal of stir in Berlin when it first appeared some months ago, has written to the Press to defend himself against the attacks made on bim charging him with being a firebrand and with having contributed by his book to further embitter the relations between Germany and England.

Herr Niemann says that Germany, the greatest of the Germanic peoples, is asserting for herself a world position. Witness ber colonies, and growing fleet. She has one enemy England. England has always been the enemy of the mighty nation because she will herself be mightiest. That is why she broke the power of the Netherlands, destroyed the Empire of Spain, and is working for two hundred years to break the might of France. She maintains ber position by utilising wars between other Powers, only engaging in wars against coloured faces. In this way England has won her colonies, and girdles the world with her haval sta tions. The more Germany's power increases, the more hostile will England grow. As soon as Germany's colonies pay, as soon as Ger many's fleet is a factor to be reckoned with, there will be a war between the two countries. According to Herr Niemann (says the Tele graph's correspondent), the Englishman's most cherished dream is England on the throne of the world, with all the other nations her vassals Herr Niemann says he wrote his book to break down the overweening vanity of Englishmen, to make the geographical and po litical state of affairs clear to his countrymen.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD,
div.p: ALEXANDRIA. B. PER DAY, WINE INCLUDED. 8.680-16.7900

The surveying ship, H.M.S. Sealark, has arrived here from Suez and will remain at this port for several months. She was formerly the yacht of Vanderbilt, the American millionaire, and was purchased from that gentleman by the British Admiralty. Since she has been here the British colony have been very pleased with Jack ashore, and the officers and men are being well looked after by their compatriots at Saskin. We are giving some sports in their honour at Graham's Point.

The British S.S. Muristas arrived here on the 28th alto, with silway material for the railway to the Nile Valley. One of the crew, who was ill with consumption, had such a fit of coughing that he bunst a blood vessel and died in the Government Hospital on Quara tine Island. His funeral took place the next day

We are all very pleased with the promotion of our popular Controller of the Bedan ports, Bimbashi Drury having been raised to the rank of Kaimakam, which carries the title of Bey with it. He is a fine specimen of an officer of the Royal Navy, and did excellent work last year on the sadd in the Upper Nile. He has also been a great success at Seakin and the news of his rise in rank has been received with great pleasure by all classes of the community.

Coles Pasha, the Director-General of the Prisons Department, arrived at Keneh yester day on board his steamer. He inspected the old prison and expressed his entire satisfaction with the cleanliness of the jails as well as with the general order in which the prison was kept He also paid a visit, to the new prison which is now being built in this town. He is expected to stay two days and then will continue his tour southwards.
A new sanitary inspector has been appointed to this Mondirish in lieu of the late Hilmy Bey. The new inspector has been promoted from Ziftah Markaz. His name is Ahmed Ef Machot.

The "Royal Navy List" for the last quarter of the current year presents all the usual features of this most useful publication, which is so increasing in bulk with every fresh issue that with the next January number the cost of the work is to be increased to 10s. per copy. The "Royal Navy List" fully maintains its position of importance as the authentic record of naval history. When it is considered that the career of some 10,000 officers is here dealt with, and that this has been possible only by the exercise of most laborious care, the book may justly rank as a complete en cyclopedia of our First Line of Defence. A carefully compiled record of the current history of the Royal Navy, from the pen of a well-known naval writer, now forms a regular feature of the work. All controversy is avoided, and the greatest care is exercised, in sifting conflicting accounts of currentevents. Especially useful are the records of the war and meritorious services of the officers of the Royal Navy, and of the Royal Marines, the Royal Naval Reserve, and the Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve (only to be found in this work), including the services of officers during the South African war, and other operations. The details of civil appoint ments held by officers on the retired lists are of great use. In the list of ships will be found recorded the victories of famous ships bearing the same name, forming an interesting and unique record of the war services of the ships. These services have been carefully revised in the present issue.
The Rye Bay List, Published quarterly, No. 108, Otober, 194. London: Wisberby & Co., 826, High Holom
